content.content: An infection caused by the Clostridioides difficile bacterium. [^70] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/E3AspGb-QA4 ### Symptoms: - Diarrhea - Fever - Belly pain - Nausea - Loss of appetite - Frequent bowel movements [^70] [C. diff Fact Sheet from CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/cdiff/pdf/Cdiff-Factsheet-P.pdf "C. diff Fact Sheet from CDC") Call the nurse if the patient “doesn’t seem right” or if the alarm goes off.[^7][^10] ![Patient-doctor [Converted] copy](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/2HO5znpyiAwkISqyEmc22m/b57939de09454651df3be1d4e51c28c7/Patient-doctor__Converted__copy.svg) __Listen to your gut or intuition. __If no one is listening to you, speak with the Nurse Manager. ### Prevention: __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") Embedded content: https://youtu.be/tZnKlFtAUDw ![handwashing](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/3Qs1rsgcAwie0O404EcMW0/6e1c030c5df8f406f93b6163dd1a1eb4/handwashing.jpeg) Healthcare providers and visitors __must wash their hands with soap and water__ and wear gloves, gowns, and/or masks (Isolation Precautions) when caring for patients who have a C. diff infection. __Soap and water are more effective at hand cleaning than hand sanitizer with a C. difficile infection.__[^71] Embedded content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l4HpcOpQaoQ All healthcare providers and visitors must wash their hands. The average handwashing rate is 40% for healthcare providers in the hospital.[^58] __Never be afraid to ask your doctor or nurse to please wash their hands!__ [Infection Prevention and You from APIC](http://www.apic.org/Resource_/TinyMceFileManager/consumers_professionals/APIC_IPandYou_YouAreImportant.pdf) [Clean Hands Count from the CDC](http://www.cdc.gov/handhygiene/pdfs/patient-factsheet-508.pdf "Clean Hands Count from the CDC") 1\. Bring in hand sanitizer for the patient, healthcare providers, and visitors to use. Ask your doctor or nurse to wash their hands __with__ you.[^7] ![hand sanitizer provider](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/2q5V25fwig4Ak4SGgiEio/4c336dc17006aa5df8d94657aac89786/hand_sanitizer_provider.jpeg) 2\. Use disinfectant wipes on all surfaces that you or the patient will come in contact with. Ask the nurse for these.[^61] ![sanitizing wipe](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/smiMs9183uw0MI8MokmSy/ee88d5019c968395e32e34a21128feed/sanitizing_wipe.jpeg) 3\. Put up a sign telling staff to wash their hands on your door and above your bed.[^7] Embedded content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M8AKTACyiB0 4\. Make sure doctors and nurses wipe the round end of the stethoscope with an alcohol wipe.[^61] 5\. Deep breathing, incentive spirometer & coughing exercises every hour while awake. __The patient should do at least 10 deep breaths every hour using the incentive spirometer while in bed.__[^78] ![incentive spirometer](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/4FE0Ueh8xi8C8aOoM8euUC/28cc668d6148ca40013aeff37a2a740a/incentive_spirometer.jpeg) 6\. Gloves need to be worn when there is contact with blood or other body fluids, mouth, nose, lungs, urinary and digestive tracts, open skin areas, or items that are soiled with blood or other body fluids. __Healthcare workers need to wash their hands both before and after using gloves. Wearing gloves is never a substitute for hand washing![^7] Gloves can have microscopic tears and holes.__ ![nitrile gloves](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/4rg2Fta5E4aeiaigMMIwEK/394f7d31c513fcc1ce76efacff603cc7/nitrile_gloves.jpeg) 7\. Healthcare providers and visitors need to follow Isolation Precautions of wearing gowns, gloves and sometimes masks if the patient's door has an Isolation Precaution sign on it. [Isolation Precaution Information from Medline](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000446.htm) ![isolation stuff](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6VTF4KABnayciesYuYEGMY/5b5f6c8e53d2c9261b6e6c7df9876595/isolation_stuff.svg) 8\. The patient must wash their hands before eating every meal and before going to sleep.[^7] 9\. The patient needs toothbrushing, &/or denture cleaning, & mouth rinsing 2-4 times every day.[^68] 10\. Cellphones are dirty.[^63][^64] - Wipe your cell phone with an alcohol wipe. - Do not take a cell phone into the bathroom. - Do not place the cell phone on the floor, especially the bathroom floor. 11\. Cover your mouth when you cough or sneeze. Use your elbow or arm instead of your hands. 12\. When a nurse is giving IV medications, make sure the nurse cleans the IV port for 15 seconds before and after with an alcohol wipe.[^65] Don’t touch __where your IV lines meet your skin__.[^66] ![iv arm](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6UwMhxhQjeYysEGk8GgiC8/b22dc225e9d6b286d7ac3995eb4faed9/iv_arm.jpeg) 13\. Tell your nurse and doctor if there is pain, swelling, redness, itching or wetness at an IV line or incision.[^7] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/67vDXQMxUz4 14\. Ask if you or the patient can have their own blood pressure cuff to be used only by them.[^7] ![stethoscope bpc](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/3rEpJHB2R2g8uu44yAe8Qc/490f0da52aec12da4fa003b064c00cab/stethoscope_bpc.jpeg) 15\. When is the soonest the patient can safely get out of bed & walk?[^68] 16\. Remove your slippers worn over socks __before getting back into your bed. This prevents germs from the floor coming into your bed.__[^7] 17\. All visitors need to:[^7] - Wash their hands before entering and leaving the room - Do not visit if they feel ill - Avoid using the patient’s bathroom [Prevention of Infections from Visitors by the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000448.htm) [^6]: Office of Disease Prevention & Health Promotion (ODPHP).
